17.11: For the life of the flesh is in the blood, and I myself have given it to you to make atonement for your lives upon the altar, because it is the blood that makes atonement by means of the life.
17.12: Therefore I have said to the Israelites: None of you shall eat blood, nor shall any alien who resides among you eat blood.
17.13: If any of the Israelites or any alien who resides among them successfully hunts wild game and takes an animal or a bird that may be eaten, he must pour out its blood and cover it with earth.
17.14: For the life of all flesh is its blood. It is its life. Therefore I have said to the Israelites: You shall not eat the blood from any flesh, for the life of all flesh is its blood. Whoever eats it will be cut off.
17.15: If any person, whether native or alien, eats anything that has died naturally or has been torn by wild animals, he shall wash his clothes, bathe in water, and remain unclean until sunset. Then he shall be clean.
17.16: But if he does not wash his clothes and bathe his body, he shall bear his guilt.

18.2:
“Speak to the Israelites and tell them this.”
I am the Lord your God.
18.3: You shall not do as they do in the land of Egypt, where you lived. You shall not do as they do in the land of Canaan, to which I am bringing you. Do not walk in their religious practices.
18.4: Follow my ordinances and keep my regulations by walking in them. I am the Lord your God.
18.5: Keep my regulations and my ordinances. Anyone who does them will have life through them. I am the Lord.
18.6: No one shall approach his own flesh and blood to uncover their nakedness. I am the Lord.
18.7: You shall not uncover the nakedness that is reserved for your father, that is, the nakedness of your mother. She is your mother. You shall not uncover her nakedness.
18.8: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s wife. It is nakedness that is reserved for your father.
18.9: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your half-sister, whether she is your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter, whether born in the household or outside it.
18.10: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter. That would be like uncovering your own nakedness.
18.11: The nakedness of the daughter of your father’s wife, the adopted child of your father—she is your sister—you shall not uncover her nakedness.
18.12: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s sister. She has the same flesh as your father.
18.13: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your mother’s sister, because she is the same flesh as your mother.
18.14: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s brother by approaching his wife. She is your aunt.
18.15: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your daughter-in-law. She is your son’s wife. You shall not uncover her nakedness.
18.16: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your brother’s wife. Her nakedness is reserved for your brother.
18.17: You shall not uncover the nakedness of both a woman and her daughter. You shall not take her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter and so uncover nakedness that belongs to her. They are her flesh. It is a depraved act.
18.18: You shall not take a woman and then take her sister as a rival by uncovering her sister’s nakedness during that first wife’s lifetime.
18.19: And you shall not approach a woman to uncover her nakedness during the period when she is unclean.
18.20: You shall not give the wife of your fellow citizen your deposit of semen for seed, so that you become unclean with her.
18.21: You shall not dedicate any of your seed to Molek, thereby defiling the name of your God. I am the Lord.
18.22: You shall not lie down with a male as you do with a woman. It is an abomination.
18.23: And you shall not give your emission to any animal, so that you become unclean by it. No woman shall stand in front of an animal to let it mate with her. It is an unnatural perversion.
18.24: You must not make yourselves unclean in any of these ways, for in all these ways the nations that I am casting out before you have made themselves unclean.
18.25: In this way the land became unclean, so I have come to deal with its guilt, and the land will vomit out its inhabitants.
18.26: But you yourselves must keep my regulations and ordinances. You must not practice any of these abominations. This applies both to the native and to the alien who resides among you.
18.27: Because the people of the land who were there before you practiced all these abominations, the land became unclean.
18.28: So do not let the land vomit you out for making it unclean, as it vomited out the nation that was there before you.
18.29: If anyone does any of these abominations, the lives of those who practice them will be cut off from the midst of their people.
18.30: Keep my instructions. Do not perform any of the abominable practices which were done before you arrived, so that you do not defile yourselves by them. I am the Lord your God.

19.2:
to speak to the whole community of the Israelites and tell them these things:
You shall be holy, because I, the Lord your God, am holy.
19.3: Each of you must respect your mother and father and keep my Sabbaths. I am the Lord your God.
19.4: You shall not turn to gods that really are not gods. You must not make for yourselves gods cast out of metal. I am the Lord your God.
19.5: When you offer a sacrifice that is a fellowship offering to the Lord, you shall offer it so that you will be accepted.
19.6: It is to be eaten on the day that you offer it or on the next day, but whatever is left over on the third day is to be burned in fire.
19.7: If it is eaten at all on the third day, it will be regarded as rotten meat. It is not acceptable.
19.8: Whoever eats it will bear his guilt, because he has desecrated what is holy to the Lord. Any such person will be cut off from his people.
19.9: When you reap the harvest from your land, you are not to finish reaping all the way to the edge of the field. Do not gather up the gleanings of your harvest.
19.10: Do not strip your vineyard clean, and do not pick up the fallen grapes from your vineyard, but leave them for the poor and the alien who live with you. I am the Lord your God.
19.11: You shall not steal. You shall not swindle. You shall not lie to one another.
19.12: You shall not swear falsely by my name so that you do not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord.
19.13: You shall not exploit your neighbor. You shall not rob him. You shall not keep the wages of a day laborer with you overnight until morning.
19.14: You shall not curse a deaf person, nor shall you put an obstacle in front of a blind person, but you must fear your God. I am the Lord.
19.15: You shall not act unjustly in court cases. Do not show favoritism to a poor person, and do not show undue honor to an important person. You must judge your fellow citizens with justice.
19.16: You shall not go around spreading slander among your people. You shall not testify falsely against your neighbor in a capital case. I am the Lord.
19.17: You shall not hate a fellow Israelite in your heart. You must openly rebuke your fellow citizen so that you do not become responsible for his sin.
19.18: You must not take revenge. You must not bear a grudge against the members of your people, but you shall love your neighbor as yourself. I am the Lord.
19.19: You shall keep my regulations. You must not cause two different kinds of livestock to mate together. You must not sow your field with two kinds of seed. You must not wear any clothing made with two kinds of material.
19.20: If a man lies down with a woman and has an emission of semen, if she is a female slave who has already been designated for another man, but she has not yet been fully ransomed or received her freedom, a hearing shall be held concerning financial compensation, but they are not to be put to death, because she had not been freed.
19.21: But he must bring his restitution offering to the Lord at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting—a ram for restitution.
19.22: The priest shall perform atonement on his behalf before the Lord with the ram for the restitution offering for his sin that he has committed, so that he may be forgiven for his sin that he has committed.
19.23: Also when you enter the land and plant any kind of fruit tree, you must cut off its budding fruit as if it were a foreskin. For three years you shall regard the tree and its fruit as uncircumcised. Its fruit shall not be eaten.
19.24: In the fourth year, all its fruit shall be set aside as a holy offering of praise to the Lord.
19.25: You may eat its fruit in the fifth year, so that its yield may be increased for you. I am the Lord your God.
19.26:
You shall not eat meat with the blood in it.
You shall not interpret omens, nor shall you perform divination.
19.27: You shall not round off the hair on the side of your heads, nor shall you disfigure the edge of your beard.
19.28: You shall not make a gash in your flesh for the dead, nor shall you put tattoos on yourselves. I am the Lord your God.
19.29: You must not defile your daughter by making her a prostitute, so that the land will not be subjected to prostitution and filled with depravity.
19.30: You must keep my Sabbaths, and you must revere my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
19.31: You must not turn to mediums or to spiritists and so become unclean through them. I am the Lord your God.
19.32: You must rise in the presence of gray hair and show respect in the presence of an elder, so that you fear your God. I am the Lord.
19.33: When an alien resides with you in your land, you must not mistreat him.
19.34: You shall treat the alien who resides with you as a fellow citizen. You shall love him as yourself, for you were aliens in the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
19.35: You shall not use dishonest measurements of weight or volume.
19.36:
Instead you must use an honest scale, honest weights, an honest dry measure, and an honest liquid measure.
I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt;
19.37: therefore, you shall keep all my requirements and my ordinances and carry them out. I am the Lord.

20.2:
to say this to the Israelites:
Any Israelite or any of the aliens who reside in Israel who give any of their children to Molek must certainly be put to death. The people of the land shall stone that person to death.
20.3: I myself will set my face against that person and cut him off from among his people, because when he gave some of his children to Molek, he made my sanctuary unclean and defiled my holy name.
20.4: Furthermore, if the people of the land deliberately shut their eyes when that man gives any of his children to Molek, and they do not put him to death,
20.5: I myself will set my face against that man and against his clan. I will cut off from among their people both that man and all those who join with him in prostituting themselves to Molek.
20.6: If any person turns to mediums or to spiritists and prostitutes himself to them, I will set my face against that person and cut him off from among his people.
20.7: You shall set yourselves apart, and you shall be holy, for I am the Lord your God.
20.8: You shall keep my regulations, and you shall put them into practice. I am the Lord, who has set you apart.
20.9: Indeed, if anybody curses his father and his mother, he must certainly be put to death. Since he has cursed his father and his mother, his blood is upon him.
20.10: If a man commits adultery with the wife of another man, if he commits adultery with the wife of his neighbor, both the adulterer and the adulteress must certainly be put to death.
20.11: If a man lies down with his father’s wife, he has uncovered nakedness that is reserved for his father. Both of them certainly must be put to death. Their blood is upon them.
20.12: If a man lies down with his daughter-in-law, both of them must be put to death. They have committed an unnatural perversion. Their blood is upon them.
20.13: If a man lies down with a male as one lies down with a woman, both of them have committed an abomination. They must certainly be put to death. Their blood is upon them.
20.14: If a man takes a woman and her mother, it is a depraved act. Both he and they shall be burned in fire, so that there may be no depravity among you.
20.15: If a man gives his emission to an animal, he must certainly be put to death, and you must kill the animal.
20.16: If a woman approaches any animal to let it mate with her, you shall kill the woman and the animal. They must certainly be put to death. Their blood is on them.
20.17: If a man takes his sister, the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother, and he sees her nakedness and she sees his nakedness, it is a shameful act. They will be cut off in the sight of their people. He has uncovered his sister’s nakedness. He will bear his guilt.
20.18: If a man lies down with a woman during her period and uncovers her nakedness, he uncovers her flow, and she uncovers her flow of blood. Both of them will be cut off from the midst of their people.
20.19: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your mother’s sister or your father’s sister, for that would be uncovering one’s own flesh. They will bear their guilt.
20.20: If a man lies down with the wife of his father’s brother, he uncovers the nakedness that is reserved for his father’s brother. They shall bear their sin. They will die childless.
20.21: If a man takes his brother’s wife, it is a polluted act. He has uncovered nakedness that is reserved for his brother. They will remain childless.
20.22: You shall keep all my regulations and all my ordinances and put them into practice, so that the land to which I am bringing you to live will not vomit you out.
20.23: You shall not walk according to the religious practices of the nation which I am casting out before you, for I was disgusted with them because they did all these things,
20.24: so I said to you, “You will take possession of their land. I myself will give it to you to possess, a land flowing with milk and honey. I, the Lord, am your God, who has distinguished you from the other peoples.
20.25: You shall therefore distinguish the clean animal from the unclean, and the unclean bird from the clean. You shall not make yourselves detestable with an animal or a bird or anything that crawls on the ground that I have distinguished by declaring what is unclean for you.
20.26: You will be holy to me, for I, the Lord, am holy, and I have distinguished you from the other peoples so that you belong to me.”
20.27: A man or a woman who is a medium or deals with the spirits of the dead must certainly be put to death. They must be stoned to death. Their blood is on them.

21.1:
The Lord told Moses to speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron, and tell them this:
No one shall make himself unclean for a dead person among his people,
21.2: except for his closest relatives. He may do it for his mother, his father, his son, his daughter, or his brother,
21.3: and also for his virgin sister, who is close to him because she does not have a husband—for her he may make himself unclean.
21.4: But he shall not make himself unclean for his relatives by marriage and so defile himself.
21.5: The priests shall not cut a bald patch on to their heads or cut off the edges of their beards or gash their bodies.
21.6: They shall be holy to their God, and they shall not defile the name of their God. Because they present offerings made by fire, the food of their God, they are to be set apart as holy.
21.7: They shall not marry a woman who has been a prostitute or is defiled. Neither shall they marry a woman divorced from her husband, for each priest is holy to his God.
21.8: So you shall treat him as holy. Since he presents the food of your God, he shall be holy to you, for I, the Lord, who sets you apart as holy, am holy.
21.9: When the daughter of a man who is a priest defiles herself through prostitution, she is defiling her father. She shall be burned in fire.
21.10: The high priest, who is greater than his brothers, on whose head the anointing oil has been poured and who has been ordained to wear the holy garments, shall not dishevel his hair nor tear his garments.
21.11: He shall not enter any place where there is a dead person. He shall not make himself unclean even for his father or his mother.
21.12: He shall not leave the sanctuary, so that he will not defile the sanctuary of his God, for the mark of consecration with the anointing oil of his God is upon him. I am the Lord.
21.13: The high priest shall marry a woman who is a virgin.
21.14: A widow or a divorcée or a woman defiled because of prostitution—these he shall not marry. Instead, he shall take a virgin from his own people as a wife,
21.15: so that he does not defile his offspring among his people, for I am the Lord, who sets him apart as holy.
21.17:
to tell Aaron this:
Any man from your offspring throughout their generations who has a defect may not approach to present the food of his God.
21.18: Indeed, any man who has a defect shall not approach—a man who is blind or lame, or who has a limb that is too short or too long,
21.19: or a man who has a crippled foot or a crippled hand,
21.20: or who is deformed or abnormally small, or who has a growth in his eye, or a festering boil, or some other disfiguring skin condition, or a damaged testicle.
21.21: Any man among the offspring of Aaron the priest who has a defect shall not draw near to present the gifts of the Lord. He has a defect, so he shall not draw near to present the food of his God.
21.22: But he may eat the food of his God from the most holy things and from the holy things.
21.23: Nevertheless, he shall not go in front of the veil and shall not approach the altar because he has a defect, so that he does not defile my holy things, for I am the Lord, who sets them apart as holy.
21.24: So Moses spoke to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites.

22.2: “Tell Aaron and his sons to be very careful with the holy things of the people of Israel, which they consecrate to me, so that they may not defile my holy name. I am the Lord.
22.3:
Tell them these things.”
In future generations, if any man among all your descendants, while he is in a state of uncleanness, approaches the holy things, which the Israelites consecrate to the Lord, that person is to be cut off from my presence. I am the Lord.
22.4:
Any man of Aaron’s descendants who has an impure skin disease or a bodily discharge shall not eat any of the holy things until he is clean.
Any man who touches anything made unclean by a dead person, or any man from whom an emission of semen goes out,
22.5: or any man who touches any swarming creature that makes him unclean, or who touches any human being who makes him unclean, whatever his uncleanness might be—
22.6: that person who touches any of these things will be unclean until sunset and shall not eat any of the holy things unless he has washed his body with water.
22.7: When the sun has gone down, he will be clean. After that he may eat from the holy things, for it is his food.
22.8: But he shall not eat anything that has died naturally or been torn by wild animals, and so become unclean by it. I am the Lord.
22.9: Aaron’s descendants shall therefore keep watch for me, so that they do not become responsible for sin on account of uncleanness and die for it because they have defiled something holy. I am the Lord, who sets them apart as holy.
22.10: No person who is not a member of a priest’s family may eat anything holy. No guest or employee of a priest may eat anything holy.
22.11: But if a priest purchases anyone with his money, that person may eat from it, and those who are born into his household may eat from his food.
22.12: If a priest’s daughter has a husband who is not a priest, she may not eat any of the holy things that have been donated as an elevated offering.
22.13: But if a priest’s daughter is widowed or divorced and she has no children and returns to her father’s house as in her youth, she may eat of her father’s food. No person who is not a member of a priest’s family may eat of it.
22.14: If anyone eats a holy thing unintentionally, he shall add one fifth of its value to it and give the holy thing to the priest.
22.15: The priests shall not defile the holy things that the Israelites donate as an elevated offering to the Lord
22.16: by letting other people eat them and so make that person incur the penalty of a restitution offering for the holy things, because I am the Lord, who sets them apart as holy.
22.18:
to speak to Aaron and his sons and the whole people of Israel and tell them this:
Whenever anyone of the house of Israel or any of the aliens residing in Israel presents their offerings—whether it is any kind of offering to fulfill a vow or any kind of voluntary offering, which may be presented to the Lord as a burnt offering—
22.19: in order for the offering to be accepted it must be a male without blemish, from the cattle or the sheep or the goats.
22.20: You shall not present any animal with a defect, because it will not be accepted on your behalf.
22.21: If anyone presents a sacrifice as a fellowship offering to the Lord from the herd or the flock to fulfill a vow or as a voluntary offering, it must be without blemish for it to be accepted on your behalf. There must not be any defect in it.
22.22: Any animal that is blind, injured, or maimed, with a growth in the eye, a festering boil, or sores—these you shall not present to the Lord. You shall not put any of these on the altar as an offering made by fire to the Lord.
22.23: You may, however, make a voluntary offering with a head of cattle or with a sheep or goat that has a long or short leg, but it will not be accepted as an offering to fulfill a vow.
22.24: You shall not present to the Lord any animal that has its testicles bruised or crushed or torn out or cut off. You shall not do this in your land.
22.25: You shall not present any of these animals from a foreigner as the food of your God. Because they are flawed, with a defect in them, they will not be accepted on your behalf.
22.26: Then the Lord told Moses this:
22.27: When a calf or a sheep or a goat is born, it shall remain with its mother for seven days. From the eighth day on, it will be acceptable as an offering that is a gift made by fire to the Lord.
22.28: But you shall not slaughter a cow or a ewe with her young on the same day.
22.29: When you offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving to the Lord, you shall sacrifice it so that you will be accepted.
22.30: It must be eaten on the same day. You shall not leave any of it over until the morning. I am the Lord.
22.31: So you shall keep my commandments by doing them. I am the Lord.
22.32: Therefore you shall not defile my holy name, so that I may be honored as holy among the Israelites. I am the Lord, who sets you apart as holy,
22.33: who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord.

23.2:
to speak to the Israelites and to tell them this:
These are the appointed times of the Lord, which you shall proclaim as holy convocations. These are my appointed times:
23.3: On six days work may be done, but on the seventh day there shall be a sabbath of complete rest, a holy convocation. You shall not do any work. It shall be a sabbath to the Lord in all the places you live.
23.4: These are the appointed times of the Lord, the holy convocations which you shall proclaim at their appointed times.
23.5: The first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, at twilight, is the Lord’s Passover,
23.6: and the fifteenth day of this month is the Festival of Unleavened Bread for the Lord. You shall eat unleavened bread for seven days.
23.7: On the first day a holy convocation is to be proclaimed for you. You shall not do any work in your regular occupation.
23.8: You shall present an offering by fire to the Lord for seven days. The seventh day shall be proclaimed as a holy convocation. You shall not do any work for your regular occupation.
23.10:
to speak to the people of Israel and tell them this:
When you enter the land that I am giving to you and you reap its harvest, and when you bring the first sheaf of your harvest to the priest
23.11: so that he may wave the sheaf before the Lord so that you will be accepted, the priest shall wave it on the day after the Sabbath.
23.12: On the day that you wave the sheaf, you shall offer as a burnt offering to the Lord a lamb without blemish, one year old.
23.13: The grain offering accompanying it is to be four quarts of fine wheat flour mixed with oil, a gift to the Lord, a pleasing aroma. The drink offering accompanying it shall be a quart of wine.
23.14: You shall not eat any of this year’s bread or roasted grain or fresh ears until this very day, until you have brought the offering of your God. This is a permanent regulation throughout your generations in all the places you live.
23.15: Then from the day after the Sabbath, from the day that you bring the sheaf to be waved, you shall count off seven weeks for yourselves. They must be complete weeks.
23.16: You shall count fifty days, until you reach the day after the seventh Sabbath. Then you shall present an offering of new grain to the Lord.
23.17: From the places where you live you shall bring two loaves of bread as a wave offering. They shall be made of four quarts of fine wheat flour, baked with yeast, as first ripe produce for the Lord.
23.18: Then with the bread you shall present seven lambs without blemish, each of them one year old, one young bull from the herd, and two rams—they shall be a whole burnt offering for the Lord, together with their grain offerings and their drink offerings, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
23.19: You shall also present the sin offering with one male goat and the fellowship offering with two one-year-old male lambs.
23.20: The priest shall wave them, together with the bread from the first ripe produce, as a wave offering before the Lord, in addition to the two lambs. They shall be holy to the Lord for the priest.
23.21: On this very same day you shall make a proclamation. A holy convocation will be proclaimed for you. You shall do no work in your regular occupation. This is a permanent regulation in all the places you live throughout your generations.
23.22: When you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not completely reap the edges of your field or gather the dropped stalks from your harvest. You shall leave them for the poor and for the resident alien. I am the Lord your God.
23.24:
to speak to the people of Israel:
In the seventh month, on the first of the month, you shall have a complete rest, a memorial celebration with loud blasts of the ram’s horn, proclaimed as a holy convocation.
23.25: You shall not do any work in your regular occupation, and you shall present a gift made by fire to the Lord.
23.27: It is the tenth day of this seventh month that is the Day of Atonement. It shall be proclaimed as a holy convocation for you. You shall humble yourselves, and you shall present an offering made by fire to the Lord.
23.28: You shall not do any work on this special day, because it is the Day of Atonement, to make atonement for you before the Lord your God.
23.29: Indeed, anyone who does not humble himself on this special day will be cut off from his people.
23.30: Anyone who does any work on this very special day, I will exterminate from the midst of his people.
23.31: You shall do no work. This is a permanent regulation throughout your generations in all your places where you live.
23.32: It is a sabbath of complete rest for you. You shall humble yourselves on the ninth day of the month at evening. From that evening until the next evening, you shall observe a sabbath rest.
23.34:
to tell the people of Israel this:
Beginning on the fifteenth day of this seventh month, celebrate the Festival of Shelters for seven days for the Lord.
23.35: On the first day proclaim a holy convocation. You shall not do any work for your regular occupation.
23.36: For seven days you shall bring an offering made by fire to the Lord. On the eighth day proclaim a holy convocation for yourselves, and you shall present an offering made by fire to the Lord. This is a closing ceremony. You shall not do any work for your regular occupation.
23.37: These are the appointed times of the Lord, which you shall proclaim as holy convocations for the presentation of offerings made by fire to the Lord—burnt offerings and grain offerings, sacrifices and drink offerings as commanded for each day.
23.38: Offer these in addition to the Sabbath offerings of the Lord, in addition to your personal wave offerings, in addition to all your offerings to fulfill a vow, and in addition to all your voluntary offerings that you give to the Lord.
23.39: Beginning exactly on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you have gathered in the produce of the land, when you go to celebrate the festival of the Lord for seven days as a pilgrim, there shall be a complete sabbath rest on the first day and a complete sabbath rest on the eighth day.
23.40: On the first day you shall select for yourselves fruit from splendid trees, branches of palm trees, boughs from leafy trees, and willows from by the stream—and you shall rejoice before the Lord your God for seven days.
23.41: Celebrate the festival for the Lord as a pilgrim for seven days each year. This is a permanent regulation throughout your generations. In the seventh month you shall celebrate the festival as a pilgrim.
23.42: You shall live in temporary shelters for seven days—every native-born person in Israel shall live in shelters—
23.43: so that your generations may know that I made the people of Israel live in shelters when I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
23.44: That is what Moses said about the appointed times of the Lord to the people of Israel.

24.2: Command the Israelites to bring you clear oil from beaten olives for the Light so the lamps will be kept burning continually.
24.3: Aaron shall set the Light before the Lord in the Tent of Meeting, outside the veil which is in front of the Testimony, every night from the evening to the morning. It is a permanent regulation throughout your generations.
24.4: He shall set the lamps regularly on the pure gold lampstand before the Lord.
24.5: You shall take fine flour and bake twelve round loaves from it. Each loaf shall be made with four quarts of flour.
24.6: You shall put them in two stacks, six to each stack, on the pure gold table before the Lord.
24.7: Upon the stacks you shall place clear frankincense as a memorial portion for the bread. It is a gift of food to the Lord.
24.8: On every Sabbath day he shall arrange it before the Lord regularly. It is a permanent covenant on behalf of the Israelites.
24.9: The bread shall belong to Aaron and his sons, who shall eat it in a holy place, for it belongs to him as a most holy thing from the gifts of food to the Lord, a perpetual allotment.
24.10: A man who was the son of an Israelite woman and of an Egyptian man came along with the Israelites. This son of the Israelite woman fought with another Israelite in the camp.
24.11: The Israelite woman’s son blasphemed the Name and cursed, so they brought him to Moses. (His mother’s name was Shelomith, daughter of Dibri, belonging to the tribe of Dan.)
24.12: They put him in custody to wait for a decision from the mouth of the Lord.
24.13: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
24.14: “Take the man who cursed outside the camp, and all those who heard it shall lay their hands on his head, and the whole community shall stone him.
24.15: Then speak to the Israelites: If anyone curses his God, he shall bear his sin,
24.16: but if anyone blasphemes the name of the Lord, he must certainly be put to death; the whole community must stone him. Whether he is an alien or a citizen, when he has blasphemed the Name, he must be put to death.”
24.17: “If anyone hits someone and kills him, he must certainly be put to death.
24.18: But one who strikes and kills an animal must make restitution for it, a life for a life.
24.19: If anyone injures his fellow citizen, he shall have the same thing done to him as he has done:
24.20: fracture for fracture, eye for eye, tooth for tooth. As he injured that other person, the same is to be done to him.
24.21: One who strikes an animal so that it dies shall make restitution for it, but one who strikes a human being and kills him shall be put to death.
24.22: You shall have the same standard of justice for the alien who lives with you and for the citizen, for I am the Lord your God.”
24.23: After Moses had spoken this to the Israelites, the man who had cursed was taken outside the camp and stoned to death. The Israelites did as the Lord had commanded Moses.

25.1: The Lord spoke to Moses at Mount Sinai,
25.2:
“Speak to the Israelites and say this to them.”
When you enter the land that I am giving to you, the land shall observe a sabbath rest for the Lord.
25.3: For six years you may sow your field, and for six years you may prune your vineyard and gather its produce.
25.4: But in the seventh year there shall be a sabbath of complete rest for the land, a sabbath for the Lord. You shall not sow your field, and you shall not prune your vineyard.
25.5: You shall not reap the produce that grows by itself from your harvest or gather the grapes from your unpruned vine. It shall be a year of complete rest for the land.
25.6: The sabbath of the land will, however, provide food for you—for you, for your male slaves and for your female slaves, for your hired workers and for your servants who are living with you temporarily as aliens working for you,
25.7: for your livestock and for the wild animals which are in your land. You may eat all its produce.
25.8: You shall count off seven weeks of years. Count off seven years seven times, so that the duration of the seven weeks of years is forty-nine years.
25.9: Then you shall sound loud blasts on the ram’s horn. In the seventh month on the tenth day, on the Day of Atonement, you are to have a ram’s horn sounded throughout your land,
25.10: so that you may set aside the fiftieth year as holy and proclaim liberty throughout the land for all its inhabitants. It shall be a Jubilee for you, so that each of you may return to his family property and each of you may return to his clan.
25.11: The fiftieth year shall be a Jubilee for you. You shall not sow the field, and you shall not reap the grain that grows by itself, and you shall not gather fruit from its unpruned vines.
25.12: Because it is a Jubilee, it shall be holy for you. You may eat its produce from the field.
25.13: In this year of Jubilee each of you shall return to his family property.
25.14: When you sell some land to your countryman, or when you buy land from your countryman, you must not cheat your brother Israelite.
25.15: When you buy from your countryman, set the price according to the number of years since the last Jubilee. When he sells it to you, he shall set the price according to the number of years of produce left till the next Jubilee.
25.16: When there are many years left, you shall increase the purchase price. When there are few years left, you shall decrease its purchase price, because what the owner is actually selling to you is the amount of produce.
25.17: So each of you must not cheat your countryman, but you shall fear your God, for I am the Lord your God.
25.18: You shall carry out my regulations, and you shall observe my ordinances. You shall carry them out, so that you may live on the land securely.
25.19: The land will yield its fruit, and you will eat your fill and live securely on it.
25.20: If you ask, “What will we eat during the seventh year, since we may not sow and we may not gather our produce?”
25.21: I will command my blessing for you in the sixth year, so that the land will yield enough produce for three years.
25.22: When you sow in the eighth year, you will still be eating from the sixth year’s crop. You will eat the sixth year’s crop until the ninth year, when its produce comes in.
25.23: But the land must not be sold without a right to recover it, for the land really belongs to me. You are actually resident aliens under my authority.
25.24: Therefore, throughout all the land that you possess, you shall grant the right of redemption for the land.
25.25: When your brother Israelite becomes so impoverished that he has to sell some of the land that he holds, his closest relative shall come and redeem what his brother has sold.
25.26: When the man who has no close relative prospers and acquires enough for the price to redeem his land,
25.27: he may calculate the years since he sold it, refund the difference to the man to whom he sold it, and return to his family property.
25.28: But if he does not acquire a sufficient amount to recover the land for himself, what he has sold shall remain under the control of the one who bought it until the year of Jubilee. It shall become free in the Jubilee, so that the seller may return to his family property.
25.29: When a man sells a house where he lives in a walled town, his right of redemption shall last until a full year after its sale. The time to redeem it lasts for a year.
25.30: But if it is not redeemed before the completion of a full year, the house which is in a town which has a wall will belong to its buyer and his descendants. It cannot be reclaimed. It will not be released in the Jubilee.
25.31: But the houses in the villages that have no wall around them shall be classified as part of the farmland. They have the right of redemption and shall become free in the Jubilee.
25.32: All the towns of the Levites and the houses in the towns which are their property have a permanent right of redemption.
25.33: Whatever a Levite is permitted to redeem (such as a house which he sold that had been his property in a city) will become free in the Jubilee, because the houses in the towns of the Levites are their possession among the Israelites.
25.34: But the pastures and fields around the Levites’ towns may not be sold, for that is their permanent possession.
25.35: When your fellow Israelite becomes so impoverished that he cannot support himself, help him as you would help a resident alien or a temporary resident. Let him retain his right to work for a livelihood among you.
25.36: You shall not take advance interest or accrued interest from him, but you shall fear your God and let your brother retain his livelihood with you.
25.37: You shall not lend him your money for advance interest or your food for accrued interest.
25.38: I am the Lord your God, who freed you from the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.
25.39: When your fellow Israelite becomes so indebted to you that he is sold to you, you shall not make him serve as a slave.
25.40: He shall remain with you as a hired laborer or a temporary resident. He shall work for you until the year of Jubilee.
25.41: Then he and his children with him will become free from your authority. He shall return to his family home and to his ancestral landholding,
25.42: for the Israelites are my servants, whom I freed from the land of Egypt. They shall not be sold in a slave sale.
25.43: You shall not rule over them harshly, but you shall fear your God.
25.44: You may buy a male slave or a female slave for yourself from the nations around you.
25.45: You may also buy some of the children of those who reside as aliens among you and some of their extended families who are born in your land, so that they become your property.
25.46: You may leave them to your children as inherited property. You may make them work as slaves for life. But as for your brothers, the Israelites, each of you must not rule over your brother harshly.
25.47: If a resident alien living among you prospers, and if your brother Israelite becomes so indebted to him that he is sold to that alien living among you or to that alien’s family,
25.48: the Israelite who has been sold shall have the right to be redeemed. One of his brothers may redeem him,
25.49: or his uncle or his cousin may redeem him, or anyone from his immediate family or extended family may redeem him, or if he prospers, he may redeem himself.
25.50: Together with his buyer, he shall calculate the elapsed time from the year that he was sold until the year of Jubilee, and the price to redeem him shall be based on that number of years. It shall be calculated as if he were a hired laborer.
25.51: If there are still many years left, he shall pay the price of redemption proportionally to the years that have passed.
25.52: If only a few years remain until the year of Jubilee, he shall calculate the redemption in this way: He shall pay the price of his redemption on the basis of his years of work,
25.53: as if he were a worker hired year by year. You shall see to it that the owner does not rule over him harshly.
25.54: If he has not been redeemed in any of these ways, he and his children with him shall become free in the year of Jubilee,
25.55: because the Israelites are servants who really belong to me. They are my servants whom I freed from the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.

26.1: You shall not make gods that are really not gods for yourselves, and you shall not set up an image or a sacred memorial stone for yourselves, and you shall not set up a carved stone relief in your land to bow down to it, for I am the Lord your God.
26.2: You shall observe my Sabbaths and revere my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
26.3: If you walk according to my regulations and keep my commandments and carry them out,
26.4: I will give you rains in their season, so that the land will yield its produce and the trees in the farmland will yield their fruit.
26.5: Threshing will last until the grape harvest, and the grape harvest will last until the time for sowing. You will eat your food until you are full, and you will live securely in your land.
26.6: I will give peace in the land so that you may lie down without anyone frightening you. I will eliminate ferocious animals from the land, and no sword will pass through your land.
26.7: You will pursue your enemies, and they will fall before you by the sword.
26.8: Five of you will pursue a hundred, and a hundred of you will pursue ten thousand, and your enemies will fall before you by the sword.
26.9: I will look on you with favor, and I will make you fruitful and will multiply you, and I will keep my covenant with you.
26.10: You will eat grain from previous harvests, grain long stored, until you remove the old grain to make room for the new.
26.11: I will place my Dwelling in your midst, and I will not at all detest you.
26.12: I will walk about in your midst, and I will be your God, and you will be my people.
26.13: I am the Lord your God, who freed you from the land of Egypt so that you would not be slaves to them. I broke the bars of your yoke so that I could make you walk upright.
26.14: But if you will not listen to me and do not obey all these commandments,
26.15: if you reject my regulations and you detest my ordinances so much that you do not obey all my commandments, so that you break my covenant,
26.16: I in turn will do this to you: I will inflict upon you panic, wasting disease, and fever, which will cause your eyes to fail and your vitality to slip away. You will sow your seed but get no return, for your enemies will eat it.
26.17: I will set my face against you. You will be beaten by your enemies, and those who hate you will rule over you. You will flee, even though nobody is pursuing you.
26.18: If, despite these things, you will not listen to me, I will go on to discipline you seven times for your sins.
26.19: I will break your proud strength and make your sky like iron and your land as hard as bronze,
26.20: so that your strength will be exhausted without accomplishing anything. Your land will not yield its produce, and the trees on the land will not yield their fruit.
26.21: If you still remain hostile to me and you are not willing to listen to me, I will multiply the plague against you seven times more according to your sins.
26.22: I will send against you the wild animals so that they will deprive you of your children and cut off your livestock. They will make you so few that your roads will be deserted.
26.23: If in spite of all these things you still refuse to be disciplined by me, and you remain hostile to me,
26.24: I will also remain hostile to you. I will strike you seven times more for your sins.
26.25: I will bring a sword on you to avenge the covenant. If you withdraw into your towns, I will send an epidemic among you, so that you will be delivered into the hand of the enemy.
26.26: When I break your supply of bread, ten women will bake your bread in a single oven. They will have to ration your bread, and though you eat, you will not be satisfied.
26.27: But if, in spite of all this, you will not listen to me and remain hostile to me,
26.28: I will remain hostile to you in anger. I myself will discipline you seven times as much for your sins.
26.29: You will eat the flesh of your sons, and you will eat the flesh of your daughters.
26.30: I will destroy your high places, cut down your incense burners, and place your corpses on the corpses of your filthy idols. With all my heart I will detest you.
26.31: I will turn your towns into a wasteland and make your holy places desolate, and I will not smell the pleasing aroma of your sacrifices.
26.32: I myself will make your land so desolate that your enemies who settle in it will be appalled at it,
26.33: while I scatter you among the nations and unsheathe my sword against you. Then your land will be a desolation, and your towns will be a wasteland.
26.34: The land will then enjoy its sabbaths during all the days of its desolation, while you are in the land of your enemies. Yes, the land will rest and enjoy its sabbaths.
26.35: All the days when it is desolate it will rest, because it did not rest on your sabbaths when you lived there.
26.36: As for those of you who survive, I will bring despair into their hearts in the lands of their enemies, so that the sound of a scattered leaf will scare them away. They will flee as though fleeing from a sword, and they will fall though no one is pursuing them.
26.37: Each of them will stumble over his brother, as if from a sword, even though no one is pursuing him. You will have no power to stand against your enemies,
26.38: and you will perish among the nations. The land of your enemies will devour you.
26.39: Those of you who survive will rot away in the lands of your enemies because of their guilt. They will rot away because of the guilt of their ancestors.
26.40: They will confess their guilt and the guilt of their ancestors because of the unfaithfulness that they committed against me, and also because they remained hostile to me.
26.41: So I in turn became hostile to them, and I brought them into the land of their enemies. So their uncircumcised hearts will then be humbled, and they will then accept the punishment for their guilt.
26.42: Then I will remember my covenant with Jacob. I will remember also my covenant with Isaac and my covenant with Abraham as well. I will remember the land.
26.43: The land will be empty of them, so that in its desolation it may enjoy its sabbaths without them, while they suffer punishment for their guilt, because, and only because, they rejected my ordinances and they detested my statutes with all their heart.
26.44: Yet, for all that, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them, and I will not detest them so much that I exterminate them. I will not annul my covenant with them, for I am the Lord their God.
26.45: I will remember in their favor the covenant to be their God that I made with their first generation, whom I freed from the land of Egypt in the sight of the nations. I am the Lord.
26.46: These are the regulations, the ordinances, and the laws that the Lord instituted between himself and the people of Israel at Mount Sinai through Moses.

27.2:
“Speak to the Israelites and say this to them.”
When a person makes a special vow to the Lord which is based on the value of different classes of people,
27.3: the set value of a male from twenty years to sixty years of age is fifty shekels of silver, using the sanctuary shekel as the standard.
27.4: If it is a female, the value is thirty shekels.
27.5: If the age is from five years to twenty years, the value is twenty shekels for a male and ten shekels for a female.
27.6: If the age is from one month to five years, the value for the male is five shekels of silver, while the value for the female is three shekels of silver.
27.7: If the age is sixty years or over, the value is fifteen shekels for a male and ten shekels for a female.
27.8: But if anyone making a dedication is too poor to pay that standard value, he shall appear before the priest with the dedicated person, and the priest shall assess a substitute valuation for the person. The priest shall assess a value on the basis of what the person who has made the vow can afford.
27.9: If what is vowed is livestock which is acceptable as an offering to the Lord, anything that a person dedicates to the Lord is set apart as holy.
27.10: He may not exchange it or substitute another for it, either good for bad, or bad for good. If he substitutes one animal for another, both the animal and its substitute are set aside as holy.
27.11: If what has been vowed is any kind of unclean livestock, which may not be presented as an offering to the Lord, he shall present the animal before the priest
27.12: so that the priest may assess it. Whatever value is set by the priest, whether high or low, will be binding.
27.13: But if he does indeed redeem it, he must add one-fifth to its value.
27.14: When a person dedicates his house as holy to the Lord, the priest shall assess it. Whatever value the priest assesses, whether high or low, will be binding.
27.15: But if the person who has dedicated his house redeems it, he must add one-fifth to its value in silver, so that it belongs to him again.
27.16: If a person dedicates any field from his family property to the Lord, its value shall be based on how much seed is needed to sow it. Land sown by six bushels of barley seed is worth fifty shekels of silver.
27.17: If he dedicates his field during the year of Jubilee, its value stands as stated,
27.18: but if he dedicates his field after the Jubilee, the priest shall recalculate its value in silver based on the number of years that are left until the next year of Jubilee, and that much will be deducted from the value.
27.19: If the person who dedicated the field redeems it, he must add one-fifth to its value in silver, so that it may be returned to him.
27.20: But if he does not redeem the field but has sold the field to another person, it may no longer be redeemed.
27.21: When the field is released on the Jubilee, it will be set aside as holy. It belongs to the Lord as a dedicated field. It belongs to the priest as his holding.
27.22: If someone dedicates to the Lord a field he has purchased that is not part of his family landholding,
27.23: the priest shall calculate the amount of value until the year of Jubilee, so that he may pay the value on that day as something holy to the Lord.
27.24: In the year of Jubilee, the field shall return to the person from whom the donor bought it, to the one to whom the landholding originally belonged.
27.25: Every value shall be based on the sanctuary shekel, which has twenty gerahs to the shekel.
27.26: However, no one may dedicate a firstborn from the livestock that has already been designated for the Lord as a firstborn, whether it is a head of cattle or a sheep or a goat. It already belongs to the Lord.
27.27: But if it is one of the unclean livestock, he may buy it back at its set value plus one-fifth. If it is not redeemed, it may be sold at its set value.
27.28: However, if anyone devotes anything that belongs to him to the Lord unconditionally, whether it is a human being or livestock or any part of his landholding, it may not be sold and may not be redeemed. Everything devoted unconditionally is most holy to the Lord.
27.29: Any person who has been devoted to destruction may not be ransomed. He must certainly be put to death.
27.30: But every tithe from the land, whether from the seed of the land or from the fruit of the trees, belongs to the Lord. It is holy to the Lord.
27.31: If anyone redeems any of his tithe, he must add one-fifth to it.
27.32: The tithe from the herd or the flock, that is, every tenth animal that passes under the staff of the shepherd, shall be set apart as holy to the Lord.
27.33: The donor must not sort out the good from the bad, and he must not make any substitutions for it. If he makes a substitution for it, then both the first animal and its substitute shall be set apart as holy. It cannot be redeemed.
27.34: These are the commandments that the Lord commanded Moses for the people of Israel at Mount Sinai.
